thread.title: Comet, lunar eclipse, and full moon all to share sky Friday
thread.title_full: Comet, lunar eclipse, and full moon all to share sky Friday - The Boston Globe

author: bostonglobe
title: Comet, lunar eclipse, and full moon all to share sky Friday
text:
NASA
In the predawn hours early Saturday morning, Comet 45P is expected to pass through the Hercules constellation.
By Andrew Grant Globe Correspondent February 10, 2017
A lunar eclipse and comet will both be visible in the sky above Boston Friday.
The astrological display will begin with a lunar eclipse that can be seen from about 5:30 p.m. to 9 p.m., said Quinn Sykes, manager of Boston University’s Judson B. Coit Observatory.
Advertisement
“The earth is going to pass in front of the moon. It’s called a penumbral lunar eclipse,” Sykes said. “The moon will darken, but not entirely like in a total eclipse.”
The best viewing time will be around 8 p.m., he said.
Get Fast Forward in your inbox: Forget yesterday's news. Get what you need today in this early-morning email. Sign Up Thank you for signing up! Sign up for more newsletters here Then, in the predawn hours, Comet 45P is expected to pass through the Hercules constellation, Sykes said.
“It will be on the verge of naked eye visibility, so if you want to see it, you better have binoculars or a telescope,” he said.
45P will be the closest a comet has come to Earth in decades, according to Slooh, a prominent astronomy organization. But it will still miss us by about 7.4 million miles as it flies by at more than 51,000 miles per hour, according to NASA.
Advertisement
Unfortunately for sky gazers, the Boston area can expect another 1-2 inches of snow starting around 8 p.m., according to the National Weather Service. This means that the sky will be cloudy, making the moon and comet hard to see.
As to the odds of a full moon, lunar eclipse and comet passing by on the same night, Sykes wouldn’t give exact numbers.
“First of all, lunar eclipses only happen during full moons and comets spend most of their time traveling through the galaxy,” he said. “This one is on a four-year cycle so it’s pure coincidence that it’s happening at the same time.”
Andrew Grant can be reached at andrew.grant@globe.com .
